ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to expand on my mathematical skills.
I learned nothing new in this course, if anything, it confused all prior knowledge I had.
I furthered my knowledge in advanced calculus and while this course was very challenging for me it improved my work ethic significantly.

This course essentially covered the topics of AP Calculus BC. Lots of integrals, series (determining convergence and divergence), parametric equations, and polar coordinates/curves. Also a good amount of derivatives.
All of single variable calculus part II. Integration techniques, series, sequences, and applications of integrals.
Calculus, analytical, problem solving,
I gained novel insights into calculus and how to approach calculus problems.
I improved my skills in calculus.
I expanded my understanding of single-variable calculus, specifically by learning methods of integration, approximations, series/sequences, areas/volumes, parametric equations, and polar equations.

I learnt about how the integral sign came to be and about the correct mathematical ways to write expressions. I learnt about critically thinking about concepts to help eliminate wrong answers, independent and group study.
Review of calculus
Learning new Math material and acquiring new skills. You acquire problem learning skills for calculus.
Having taken this course, I feel much more confident solving integrals, convergence and divergence tests, volumes of revolutions, and parametric equations.
Equivalent to Calc BC/II knowledge (integrals, series, volumes and areas, polar and parametric equations). How to learn from a textbook.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think understanding of course material varied from section to section because of TFs. Some handed out worksheets for every class that was very helpful, others (mine) just spit balled, rambled, and got mad when the class expressed confusion.
The course failed properly teach any mathematical concepts.

Strengths of the course are that it is straight forward and the textbook coincided with the material taught in class. However, I did not learn from class as much as I would have liked which resulted in me always feeling behind in class and putting in a huge amount of work while not being extremely pleased with my results.

A strength of this course is the organized structure. The topics are logically ordered, and you can generally tell when one unit has ended and the other has begun. On the midterms, this meant that it was relatively easy to understand which topics you were expected to know for a given test. I usually prefer this course format to one where there are no clearly defined lesson topics or units. A weakness is that the course sections are all taught by different professors, which can mean that the teaching is not fully standardized. Depending on your professor, you might have a better experience in this course than others.

The problem sets were helpful and the extensive time that peer tutors were available was also great. Another strength were the concept checks and practice exams before each exam. A weakness in the course was that the problem sets were always due on Wednesday while some classes meet on a Monday Wednesday schedule and some on Tuesday Thursday. This meant some classes were teaching information on Thursday after the relevant problem set was due. This was not an  effective learning strategy because students had to teach themselves or rely on the peer tutors to teach new information when that should be the instructors job.  This would be improved by making the problem sets due on Thursday nights. Also, another weakness would be the fact that there are many different sections with different instructors but all students take the same tests. Then, the exams dont seem to test whether or not we learned the material, but whether or not our teachers taught the right material. Maybe a solution would be to provide clearer information in the umbrella course tab about the expected knowledge going into each test.
The strengths were the peer tutoring and practice problems provided. The weakness was definitely the p-sets as they were much harder and more difficult than the exams.

The smaller class sizes were nice to be able to ask more questions to the teachers, however this increase in classes resulted in the math professor only teaching one section, while the rest were taught by grad students who had much less experience teaching.

This course was organized in ensuring that assignments and due dates were very clear and there were many opportunities to work with peer tutors/professors one-on-one for clarification. The Explorations provided a basic understanding of material that would be reviewed in class, but topics could be explored further in class. This course could be most improved by ensuring that professors were all on the same page regarding material and teaching methods (some were much better than others).

I originally didnt like the idea of Riemann sums because I thought if we just had the integral we should just find the exact integral rather than estimate but sometimes its good to know the origin. I also like that presentation matters because it gets us to work neater. The module videos also help. I do wish there were more professors that were easier to understand.
Lessons were not planned well, had to self-study. Review sessions were helpful. Exams were very theoretical compared to practice we had in class
The exams are harder than what we are given in homework or what we do in class. The class instructor should do with us harder examples so that we know what to expect in exams.

The strength of this course was probably peer tutor office hours. If not for them, I would probably struggle a lot in this class. The number of office hours with the professor, however, could have been increased.

Strengths: Curriculum is well organized. Plenty of resources for students to succeed (review sessions, practice exams, peer tutor hours, problem sets).
Weaknesses: Quality of learning is very dependent on your professor!! Felt bored and like I was learning out of a textbook most times but it could depend on your interest in the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to future students. Calculus is a fascinating part of math, that once mastered, is quite rewarding.
Yes, but it is hard because you have to be sure of your TF first.

I would not recommend this course to another student. I took both AB and BC calculus in high school, therefore the material was familiar. However, this course only proved to frustrate me and I felt as if most work was busy work.
Only if you are really interested and love math and want to continue with math. Also, I highly recommend having taken BC calculus, it would make this course significantly easier.

Yes, for those who need Calc II or a QR course as a prerequisite. It is also a solid course for people needing a standard math class, whereas MATH 116 is meant to have applications to biology and tends to go beyond the scope of Calc II. I would also recommend choosing your specific section with consideration for the professor teaching, if possible.
Yes, this is a great foundational math course.
Yes, because there were many great resources and the pace wasnt too fast. The workload was manageable.
Yes I would.
yes, however mainly because it is one of few courses available for a student to take to fulfill many math requirements.
I would recommend this course to a student that needed Math 115 as a prerequisite or wanted to tune up their Calculus BC
Yes, I think that the work is manageable and the class is engaging.
I would recommend to t just because you learn new things, and even if you may not like your professors teaching skills its a great way to start to seek out for help and work with others.
Yes if you need to take calculus
I would recommend this class. You will build upon your previous math skills and learn new interesting content.
I would recommend it only if you have it as a requirement. I would not bother with it if I didn't need to take a math class.

Would only recommend if it is a necessary requirement or pre-req. Course may feel demanding and fast-paced depending on the professor but the content is straight-forward and bland unless you love foundational calculus.
